Set-up checklist:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Range Set-up

•Target backstops – Set up target backstops against a durable wall or barrier if possible. What can a backstop be made out of? Click here to see some examples.

 

•Assisting Staff - task senior cadets or other staff to assist with the firing point, ammunition point, relay organization, sentry duty, and the conduct of concurrent activities. In addition, one Standard First Aid qualified person (minimum)  must be tasked to provide first aid.

•Emergency communications – ensure quick access to a phone in case of an emergency. Check for cell phone signal before commencing, if using one for emergencies.

 

•Security/boundaries – ensure people can’t accidentally enter the danger are template. Physically block off access, post sentries, and/or post warning signs, etc.

 

•Lighting – add more lights if required to minimize shadows, and ensure even lighting across all targets.

 

•Hazards – select an open and  flat area to set up a range, free of obstacles and hazards (especially those that could cause pellets to ricochet back at shooters).

Backstop.  A device, land feature or object used to stop a pellet after it passes through or around the target.  An effective backstop will minimize ricochets and prevent damage to property and personnel caused by pellets leaving the range area.

The portable backstop and target frame in the picture above has a sheet of cardboard slid from the top into the frame. You can see the hinged sheet of plywood attached behind the backstop that holds it up. A sheet of ballistic cloth is suspended behind the cardboard to stop and trap the pellets, making clean-up easier.

The picture above shows wood-framed target backstops (often called “portable backstops”) that have been illuminated, aligned and numbered for a competition. The frames are numbered from left to right.

Outdoor rifle range with biathlon style targets.

The earth mound (berm) behind the targets is the backstop, and solid wooden walls have been built to reduce the danger area. For air rifle ranges, a berm must be at least 3 metres in height.

Wood frame backstops on an outdoor range.

The fencing behind is intended to stop stray pellets (reducing the danger area template which would otherwise be 250m).
